utterance.speaker: Note 1
utterance.content: House is physically in Nolan’s office for the entire episode and describes other scenes to Nolan. Because of this, cuts between locations are not as clearly defined in the transcript as they usually are. If the same scene shifts from being what House is talking about and back to Nolan’s office, the cuts are more likely to be identified within the usual descriptions.

utterance.speaker: Note 2
utterance.content: In an interview, David Foster said that as House envisions the other locations he sometimes includes an object from Nolan’s office. This happens once in each of the six acts. These have been identified in the transcript for acts 2, 4 and 6. If you find the objects from the other three acts, please leave a comment as to what and where it is. If I see it too, I’ll add it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay. "Therafy" me.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: You're late.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're fat.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: It's unusual.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know how far the parking lot is? My leg's been hurting.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Anything been on your mind lately, any particular stress?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. Probably just gonna rain.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Mm-hmm. You like the new Monet reproduction in the waiting room — the Water Lilies?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was late. I wasn't focusing on the decor, but it sounds appropriately bland and calming.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Stress can also make you absentminded.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm not stressed… Beyond the stress induced by you telling me how stressed I am.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Just an ordinary week. Okay. Tell me about it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I had a patient.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House. Good. I have a case for you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Beer?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Amnesia. She was found jogging in the street, disoriented. She almost got hit by a truck. The MRI showed no abnormalities. No I.D. on her. Just her jogging clothes and her heart rate monitor. We know absolutely nothing about her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We know she has money. Blaze Outriggers — 400 bucks a pair. People who have money don't just disappear. Sooner or later, someone's gonna show up looking for her.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: She just ate 15 minutes ago. She keeps forgetting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don't eat because you remember it's time to eat. You eat 'cause you're hungry. Her metabolism is in high gear. She is an extreme long-distance runner—

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Why were you in the ER?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's your question? You're a psychotherapist. You're hearing about a great amnesia case, and all you're asking me is geography.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Just curious.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was avoiding Wilson. It's not something you couldn't have seen eight miles away.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wilson's a processor. I knew there were some things that he'd want to process with me… at length.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Sam's moving in.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If it's before Friday, your assistant wins the pool.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I was just wondering what your plans were.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tonight?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: In life. Sam likes you…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But she wants me to move out.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. I want you to move out. I didn't know things with Sam would happen so quickly. I d–I don't want to make a mistake here. I've made a lot of mistakes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: By moving too quickly. Given your usual rate of commitment, I'm surprised you're not already re-divorced.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I could help you find a place.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What's wrong with my old place?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Nothing. I just thought… You might want to find somewhere new, somewhere…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where I didn't abuse drugs and hallucinate.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm fine.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: You're fine? Your best friend is tossing you out, and you're fine?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why wouldn't I be?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: You're not feeling a little… betrayed and angry? Wilson bought a two-bedroom condo specifically so that you could move in with him. It wasn't that long ago. You don't feel a little… jerked around?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He couldn't foresee Sam coming back into his life.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: That's a very rational defense of your friend. And, uh, I'm not buying it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Based on what?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Based on the fact that you were late, and you didn't notice the pictures in the outer office.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Those aren't symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: They are to me. And here's another one. You took the case. Hmm? No negotiating, no bargaining. No clinic hours changed hands. Were you looking for something to distract you from the fact that your best friend just threw you out?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Case was interesting.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: It's not organic. It's not mysterious. Most likely some psychologically traumatic event occurred that made the patient's brain choose to forget everything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or not.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Here. Loss of differentiation between gray and white matter.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It's subtle.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: But it's in the area that controls memory. Not likely it's a coincidence.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Bacterial infection?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Do I need to know this?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fine. I'll give you the Cliff Notes version. Chase – MS, Taub – physical trauma. I can tell you why we ruled them out.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Or not.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Then it's probably a toxin, and we need to find it before it kills her. We should search her house.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Good luck with that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Her heart rate monitor has a serial number. The distributor can match the number to the store that sold it. She's a serious athlete. She might have been there often enough to be remembered.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Brilliant.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Did he really say that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Subtextually.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Long shot.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Even if the store clerk doesn't know who she is, the store's probably close to where she lives. Just seeing those surroundings might spark a memory.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You want us to take her there?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. I'll take her.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Really? Uh, it's unusual for you to spend time with a patient, isn't it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Patients are boring… As people. This one I'm sure was no exception, but her situation was interesting. Besides, I was still avoiding Wilson. And no better way to avoid than leaving the hospital.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Maybe. Or were you avoiding going home? There's a reason they tell addicts to stay away from old geography.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I wasn't avoiding going home. I'd already gone home…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Before I came into work that day. I went straight there from Wilson's.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: Hey, take it easy! You're gonna kill me! God, why don't people knock? House, it's you! Where you been? Hold up a second.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Alvie? Juan Alvarez — you let him stay at your place?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not exactly.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: I was beginning to wonder if you were ever gonna show up. Su casa, mi casa. Casa!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why are you here?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: When I left Mayfield, I went back to the old neighborhood. You know, you shouldn't leave the bathroom window unlocked.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, thanks for the safety lesson. Why are you here?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: Like I said, when I went back to the neighborhood, I found out immigration was looking for me. So I decided to visit my old buddy House!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And turn his apartment into a giant prison jumpsuit.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: Juan Alvarez is no freeloader. I do my part, earn my keep. The first week I made your dinner, but you never showed up. The second week I organized your stuff.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My stuff?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: But still, you never showed up. So this week, since I'm a real good painter, I decided to—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Coffee table — where'd you put it? In the bedroom?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: The paint's not cheap, House. It's a custom color. It's a mix of titanium, yellow, and ochre. Ochre — I don't even like that stuff. It's like a fruit. It's got hair on it. But they say it's a vegetable—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You sold my table to pay for paint that I don't want?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: I had to sell some other things too.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get out.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: No, papa, just give the color a chance.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Look, I'm going to work now. And when I come back, the walls will be a less exciting color, and you will be gone.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: So Wilson threw you out, and you threw Alvie out — just, uh, another week?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unlike me, Alvie didn't leave. I took my motorcycle to work that day. When I went home to get my car, he was painting the ceiling magenta. So I brought him with me to protect the apartment.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: To protect the apartment. Whoa. Deja vu.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Tossing him out or, uh, sending him to the movies or, uh, locking him in the bathroom would also minimize Alvie's destructive force. But you chose his company deliberately. Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Obviously because he's a Wilson substitute. You can barely tell the difference between them, especially when Wilson raps about the hood.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: I'm not suggesting Alvie's a substitute, but he would make a great distraction.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: From what?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: That's what I'm trying to find out. Go on.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: Maybe the heart rate monitor was a gift. That's why no one recognized her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shut up, Alvie. Anything familiar… Church, grocery store?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: It's okay, Ms. X. Maybe she's never been to this town before, bought the heart rate monitor on the store's website.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know that Puerto Ricans are U.S. citizens, right? Instead of working the case, why don't you contemplate the inanity of an American with American immigration issues?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: I had a birth certificate. I lost it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So get a new one.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: I tried that, House. But the town hall had burned down when I was a kid, destroyed the records.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There's only one copy?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: They tried to make me fill out a whole bunch of forms before they'd give it to me. I decided it would be quicker and easier to do it myself.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How'd that go?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: They figured out it was forged. And now, for some reason, they don't believe anything I say. They actually think I'm lying about being Puerto Rican. Told me I had to go to a special hearing to prove it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then someone will show up — a spouse, a friend — to tell you who you really are and what you should be feeling. They always do.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What did they say at the hearing?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: I didn't go. I lied once.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your mother is Puerto Rican, therefore, you are Puerto Rican. All you got to do is prove your mom's your mom, find some documentation—

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: People like that don't listen to people like me. Doughnuts! Hey, House, let's get doughnuts!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Alvie, the hearing—

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: Everyone loves doughnuts — glazed, crullers, elephant ears, even doughnut holes. Much better than the sporting goods store. I bet Mrs. X went there all the time.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We're not here— And then I realized… You make a good point.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: Really? I was making that up.

utterance.speaker: Durdanna
utterance.content: Dozen glazed, dozen jelly-filled? You want the usual, right?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your old friend, the fried carbohydrate. She needed the calorically dense food to support the running habit. Do you know her name?

utterance.speaker: Durdanna
utterance.content: Sandy… Or Shelley. I don't know. The guy she's with called her that once. I just work here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do you know where they live?

utterance.speaker: Durdanna
utterance.content: He left a business card in our free doughnut jar. It's up on the wall of winners.

utterance.speaker: Jay
utterance.content: Sidney. God, I was so worried about you. What happened?

utterance.speaker: Jay
utterance.content: The police said it was too soon to do anything, so I started calling hospitals on my own. Princeton Plainsboro wasn't even on my list. You really think something around here could have made her sick?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Here, work, anywhere she could have been exposed. Why wasn't Princeton Plainsboro on your list?

utterance.speaker: Jay
utterance.content: Well, I mean, it's a long way to run, even for her.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: What is it I do besides run?

utterance.speaker: Jay
utterance.content: You're a lawyer — civil rights, class action suits. It's a stressful job. Running's the way you deal with it.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: That doesn't sound like me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do you have any idea what would sound like you?

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: Good point.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: So what were you thinking during all this?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That it was a strange position to be in. At that moment, she was more comfortable with me than with her husband. And he was picking up on it.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: What about you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What about me how?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Well, there was a sort of, um, artificial intimacy between you? She had been dependent on you. Uh, did you find that attractive on some level? Disturbing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Those are my two choices? None of the above. She was just a patient. She was interesting.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: So we're really… married?

utterance.speaker: Jay
utterance.content: For four years.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: Ms. X, you lead a lemon fresh life. Found three different cleansers under the sink. Cleaned out the medicine cabinets too.

utterance.speaker: Jay
utterance.content: You know, she just won a settlement for some families whose housing development was built on an old methane field.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Toxic exposure to methane could explain this.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: I surf?

utterance.speaker: Jay
utterance.content: You stopped before we met. You've been too busy.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: And we're married?

utterance.speaker: Jay
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: All right, it's nothing personal. Bet she didn't think you were her type back when you first met either.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We'll take her back to the hospital, test her blood and urine and start treatment.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: Oh! I'm all right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What happened?

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: I don't know. My foot suddenly went numb.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: Her pants are wet.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Urinary incontinence. She's having complex partial seizures. This isn't methane. And you can leave the bucket. We need to get her to—

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Seizures? This is the second diagnosis you've come up with that has a personal resonance for you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm choosing my diagnoses based on personal issues? You think she fell down the stairs and peed her pants 'cause Wilson dumped her too?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: You're choosing to tell me about this case, so let's look at it. First you were fixated on a harmful toxin from her past, possibly because you're worried about a harmful toxin from your own past.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Chase had the toxin idea. Maybe he's obsessed with my past.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: And–and now you're talking about a seizure disorder?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which is also not a toxin.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: But which is most likely caused by an old injury to the brain. Wh–why do you see your past as such a threat?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not only am I unthreatened by it, I was trying to get it back.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There's a ding mark.

utterance.speaker: Dutch
utterance.content: It's a piece of junk. It was dinged when it came in.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure, the–the cup marks and the scuffs and the paint and those three chips. This fourth one’s new.

utterance.speaker: Dutch
utterance.content: I run a pawn shop, not a storage company. Do you want it or not?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: That should be it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You said you pawned five books. There's only four.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: That's all there is.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where's “Approach to the Acute Abdomen”?

utterance.speaker: Dutch
utterance.content: Sold it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: To?

utterance.speaker: Dutch
utterance.content: I can't tell you. It's a law, and should be. Crazy bastards like you try to hunt down their stuff.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How much for the pile?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You said it was junk.

utterance.speaker: Dutch
utterance.content: No, no. It's your junk. You want it. $500. Take it or leave it.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Why is it so important that you get your stuff back?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unlike the rest of humanity… Who's okay when their belongings are taken. Everyone wants their stuff. That's why it's their stuff.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Everyone doesn't pay five times what it's worth.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I like my stuff. I hate it when Wilson moves it—

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Oh…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is not about Wilson! Say it.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: I wasn't gonna say anything.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: First down!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: One more, you get a touchdown.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: Whoo!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hike!

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: Huh! House, you can't run for the touchdown.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And… hike!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because I thought you were a smart guy who didn't need the obvious spelled out to him. Wilson noticed that I didn't come to my office all day. He came to find me, wanted to make sure I'm okay — boring, boring, boring.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Um, but you thought it was important to tell me about Nerf football? Sorry. Your story. Continue.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: House, House, stop! Stop, stop, stop.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You okay?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: Yeah. It was my mother's. She died when I was four. It's all I have left.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's very sad, Alvie. Listen, I set up an immigration hearing.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: No, House, I'm gonna end up in jail or worse — the Dominican or someplace. Que se yo. Que no.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Um, interesting. You present yourself as, uh, not giving a damn about other people's emotions, but your actions indicate otherwise. You dismiss Alvie's story about his mother, but you cared enough to schedule a hearing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I cared for eight seconds. Then I got distracted.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We've kept the patient up for 12 hours now. No hint of seizure-like activity. We should shut this down.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Try a strobe light, add more stress.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I think there's plenty of stress in here.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: Don't we ever do anything but work?

utterance.speaker: Jay
utterance.content: You run.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: That's just more work. What about fun? God, how can we be this boring?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Apparently, without her memory, the patient's personality has returned to what you might call its “natural state.”

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Seems she had a wake-up call while she was at college. Her brother died in a car accident. She decided to make her life mean something. Went to law school. Now that's all gone.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: The thing that caused the change is gone… So the change itself is gone.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. I knew the psychological aspects of this case would interest you. Bet you got a theory already. What is it?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: It's not relevant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What is it?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Why do you care about my theory?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I think he just… bores her. She's at an earlier stage of development. She's looking at her grown-up future, and it puts her to sleep.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: If he just bored her, she'd hide it to be polite. Their problem is synchronicity. Just like you and me, House, they're not on the same page. He talks to her like someone he shares history with. But from her point of view, he's a stranger forcing intimacy on her. Of course she doesn't like him. He's not helping. He can feel he's losing his wife, and it makes him come on stronger.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He almost did lose his wife.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The breathing problem was caused by fluid overload in the lungs.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Diabetes insipidus.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: And the D.I. came from damage to the hypothalamus.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hypothalamus here, hence the D.I. and incontinence. The amygdala here, hence the global amnesia. And the motor cortex —that's the foot paralysis. What do they all have in common?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It ends with a diagnosis of spongiform encephalitis. I convinced the team to cut out part of this woman's brain. That's not interesting to you?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not even if it's the amygdala? She'll lose all her long-term memory.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Well, this is where you tell me that being cavalier with someone else's past has nothing to do with avoiding your own past. The case is irrelevant. You just found it, uh… interesting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Aren't therapists supposed to be nurturing?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Nowhere… is that in the manual. Look, you–you've been in therapy for a year. You know when I ask you to talk about anything, I mean anything that affects you —what upset you, what made you mad or relieved or joyful. You want me to believe that this case means nothing? Then, um… why should I listen to it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are you charging me for this time?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is ridiculous.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: What's that? On the back of your arm?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's just a bruise. And I fell.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: You remember falling?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. I was drunk… Hence the balance issues.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Well, it looks like you fell on the tip of someone's boot.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I said something that someone objected to.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Well, if you don't remember, then how can you—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's usually the way it is when someone hits me. People who kick when you're down are jerks, but they're generally not irrational jerks.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: You got drunk enough to get into a bar fight and not remember, and you've been insisting that everything's fine? W–why–why go out and get blind drunk? Were you looking for a fight?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't know.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: What have you screwed up?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: You say that when you've been hit in the past, it's because you provoked it with something that you said, which means you're well aware of the risks. So on some level, you were in that bar looking for someone to hurt you. Logically, people punish themselves for something they did or something they didn't do. So what… did you screw up?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't know. Okay, there may be a problem.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: All right… Let's talk about Wilson.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I told him your book was contaminated with Anthrax spores. Then I gave him $300. The address of the buyer. Maybe I was hasty in asking you to move out. Why don't you stay with me and Sam for a little while? There's no need to hurry things.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What prompted this?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Look, the whole idea was that after Mayfield, you wouldn't be on your own. I can touch base with you a lot more easily if you're staying with me than—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: God's sake, Wilson. You really span the chasm from wishy to washy. If you're gonna be an ass, be an ass. Stick with it.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Why were you being so hard on the guy, when he was being conciliatory?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Come on. Cuddy played on his guilt. She put him up to this.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: How do you know that? How do you know this wasn't entirely his own idea?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Two reasons — first, he wants to create the perfect environment to be with Sam. He's been thinking about asking me to leave for a while. Finally he does it and immediately turns around and changes his mind? No. He talked to somebody.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Maybe it was Sam.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, that's a possibility.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I want this to be the last serious relationship I ever have. I want this to be the one.

utterance.speaker: Sam
utterance.content: Me too. Where's House? It's not as meaningful without him.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Okay, um… Not Sam. Uh, that still doesn't answer why Cuddy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because they've been talking about me. She called me to check on the patient, which she never does without a reason. I asked why, and she said…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She's a barracuda attorney, House. These are the kind of patients we like to keep happy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right now the patient's lucky if she can spell jurisprudence.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yeah, but when she gets that memory back, which we are trying to make happen, she'll be able to spell lawsuit. I'm just touching base.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Touching base. Wilson used exactly the same phrase. Colluding about me is their favorite pastime.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Okay, you think they talked. How do you think that conversation went?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm worried about House.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Me too. Couldn't you have waited? It's way too early for him to be on his own, back in the old apartment. What makes you think he can handle it?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I offered to find him a new place.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You have to let him back into your condo.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Sam and I just got him out of the condo.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You know what House is like. He's self-destructive.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Without constant supervision, he's gonna slide back into drugs. If you're not watching him, I've got to.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: So they don't trust you. They assume you'll fail. Are these their fears or yours?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Let's turn on the lights, Hmm? In your brain. Maybe they did talk about you, but… How do you know it didn't happen like this?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm worried about House.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It's the first time he'll be on his own since Mayfield.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Now you're being overprotective. House doesn't need to be wrapped in cotton wool. But you know that, or you wouldn't have asked him to move out.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Okay. I guess this is really about me. It's just… I feel like a jerk. Sure, Sam and I are gonna want to be on our own eventually, but I kind of sprang this on him. The right way would have been to just tell him to take as long as he needed, that there's no hurry.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: So it's not what you did, but how you did it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: That matters in a friendship. I need to fix this.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Why don't you talk to him about moving back in? Just touch base.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We're having a consent issue with the patient.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Wait a minute. Taub's not here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, he is.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We're having a consent issue with the patient.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: What's Taub doing in my imaginary version of a scene with Wilson and Cuddy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your version needed to be ended, 'cause it's crap. It's all sweetness and light and… faith that I'm gonna choose the right path. Yeah, that sounds like Wilson.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: I have as much evidence for mine as you do for yours. I know Wilson's your friend. So he could be wondering if he did right by you. And I know he wouldn't have asked you to move out in the first place unless he was convinced you could handle life on your own.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And I know that he and Cuddy have gone behind my back before to strategize about the House problem.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: So there's truth in both versions. But you choose to focus on the parts that make you uncomfortable. So… Why are you and Wilson… friends? Do you think this friendship is the best you can do?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wilson is not a consolation prize.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: There… You're defending him. And a minute ago, he was skulking around in the background like some sort of manipulative Iago.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He's my friend.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: So what do you value in him?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can say whatever I want to him, and he'll never leave.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: He's sort of leaving. At least, he won't be around as much… because he's putting Sam first.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: For now. After the divorce, he'll probably ask me to move in again. I take the long view.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: You say that to Wilson?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are you kidding? That's the kind of remark that leads people to hit you.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Uh, maybe you've been right from the beginning. Maybe this isn't about Wilson.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You say that now that I finally agree with you? Do you just argue the opposite of whatever I say?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: I don't mean the Wilson thing doesn't, uh, bother you, uh, but it sounds like he's the closest you can come to a safe relationship. You'd have to do something major to screw it up. Um, what–what else have you been involved in this week? What would you want to punish yourself for?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I told you, I don't know.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Okay, um, let's approach it from a different angle. Have you gotten any other people angry at you over anything?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, yeah. That's why I called it an ordinary week.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Okay. Tell me about it.

utterance.speaker: Jay
utterance.content: You'd be losing a part of your brain.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: It is my brain. Why is it not my right to consent?

utterance.speaker: Jay
utterance.content: I'm sorry, but… I'll take this to court if necessary. All right, Sidney's in no position to make decisions about herself right now. She doesn't even know who she is.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: I read your consent form, and I understood it. I want the surgery.

utterance.speaker: Jay
utterance.content: Why wouldn't she? Of course she's willing to risk losing her memories permanently. She has no idea how important those memories are. Does she even know what risk is? She's never lost anything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Without the surgery, she'll lose everything. The prion infection will continue to advance and destroy her whole brain.

utterance.speaker: Jay
utterance.content: Well, there has to be another way. Please. I'm speaking for my wife, the wife I lived with for four years who isn't here and can't defend herself. Dr. House, are you listening?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, you can stop arguing, 'cause it doesn't matter anymore. Look at the variability in the heart rate. The S.E. has spread into the brain stem.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: W–wherever it is, you–you can still cut it out.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No. We can't cut the brain stem.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This thing's moving too quickly. Surgery's no longer an option, which I guess means you've won. Congratulations. Put in a pacer and start her on chemo and radiation. It won't cure her, but it'll buy a couple weeks so she can find out who she is before she dies.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: That was pretty rough Do you always break the news to your patients that way? Or were you short-handing it for me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Husband was being an idiot.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Well, he was asking for it. But, um, to punish him you have to punish the wife too. Why–why did he make you so angry, Hmm? Because he didn't want to cooperate with you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He'd rather risk his wife's life than their marriage. People's brains stop working when they think they're gonna lose someone they love.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Your leg hurt?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's all right.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Okay. Anyone else you pissed off?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 50 bucks for the book.

utterance.speaker: Harris
utterance.content: Forget it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You paid $25. That's 100% return.

utterance.speaker: Harris
utterance.content: That's what I paid. But it's a rare surgical text, nearly 100 years old — plates in mint condition. That book's worth several thousand dollars.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: $2,000. I'll write you a check.

utterance.speaker: Harris
utterance.content: Nice try. Face it — I had the wit to recognize something valuable when I saw it. In the great Darwinian race, I get my just reward. You become road kill.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: Yo, House, you want to stop by the library? 'Cause I got a book to return. Ta-ka-plow!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Anyone see you?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: Yeah, prof saw me walking down the driveway. He said the roses need more fertilizer.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: I didn't know there was a section of the brain just for hope.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's very, very tiny.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We used fluoroscopy to guide pacemaker placement in the patient's heart.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Hello. Rapidly progressive dilated cardiomyopathy. This isn't S.E., and whatever it is, it's not just in her brain. It's attacking her whole body.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: You work for House? I guess we're teammates. Isn't that cool?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Durkee
utterance.content: Juan Alvarez?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: What the hell?

utterance.speaker: Durkee
utterance.content: We're taking you into custody — deportation order.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: I'm a citizen. You're disrespecting Puerto Rico.

utterance.speaker: Durkee
utterance.content: If you're a citizen, why'd you miss your hearing?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: You called them?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What's going on?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We're trying to stabilize her heart. She's still tachy and hypotensive.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Brain, heart, and rapidly progressing.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Endocarditis — slow-moving infection in her heart throws clots to her brain.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: I'm not talking to you. How could you turn me in?

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: I don't like you, House. I hate you.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Even I.V. Antibiotics will take time to work.

utterance.speaker: Court Officer
utterance.content: A gentle reminder — the use of cell phones is prohibited.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Give her the first dose directly into the lungs in the O.R.

utterance.speaker: Court Officer
utterance.content: Before the less gentle arrest for contempt.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Put her in an isolation room with U.V. light. And get yourselves tested. You've all been exposed.

utterance.speaker: Court Officer
utterance.content: Docket number 4378.

utterance.speaker: Public Defender
utterance.content: You are?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I am Mr. Alvarez's doctor.

utterance.speaker: Public Defender
utterance.content: Your honor, DNA evidence proving the matriarchal lineage of Juan Alvarez.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: My mother's DNA was still on that cross?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It could be.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: You faked it? It wasn't just me. You lied to them too!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm better at it than you are.

utterance.speaker: Alvie
utterance.content: I'm gonna repaint your whole apartment now, make the drapes match the carpet now!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Lungs sound wet. O-2 sats are dropping.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: May need to tube her. Grab some I.V. furosemide.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wait, wait.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She's crashing.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We need to get her on a vent.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There's something on her ankle.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Tattoo.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: "Eddie would go." It's a surfing phrase. Must be from her earlier life.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: So you were right… in the end. It was her past. Did she get her memory back?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not yet.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Will she?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No way to know.

utterance.speaker: Sidney
utterance.content: I think roses are my favorite. But I guess I told you that at some point.

utterance.speaker: Jay
utterance.content: I don't remember.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: He's treating her as though they just met. He's courting her. Whose idea was that? He was doing the opposite of everything he should. Suddenly he's changed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Taub thought it might—

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: That was your idea. And you asked me what I thought was going on between them. It's their relationship that's on your mind. That's why you've been thinking about this case — relationships. Lost one with Wilson, gained one with Alvie.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not exactly.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Alvie?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: You gonna tell me what the note said?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Alvie was very grateful that I'd gotten him out of trouble. It allowed him to go stay with his cousin in Phoenix without worrying about immigration looking for him there.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: You didn't think he was gonna stay forever.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: What happened next?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nothing happened next.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's all I got.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Relationships.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Bergman. What do you want me to say?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: I don't know. You're the one who set the theme — something about relationships made you go out and provoke a fight. Wilson and Sam have a relationship. You're not thrilled about it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They're happy. Why should I screw that up? Everyone's happy. Everyone's moving in together — Wilson and Sam, Cuddy and Lucas. Even Alvie's—

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Cuddy and Lucas are moving in together? You didn't mention that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They talked about moving in together before. It's not big news.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Cuddy… Cuddy. “Approach to the Acute Abdomen”… Written by Ernest T. Cuddy, M.D. Any relation to your Cuddy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Her great-grandfather. I've had it for years… Always meant to give it to her for a special occasion.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: Like her… housewarming?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's just a gift.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: A woman you care about is taking one step further away from you and closer to someone else? I–I think I can safely say yes, it's significant if you don't mention it. You were willing to punish the husband of your patient because you identified with him. He was also losing someone he loved.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm not gonna go out and get hammered because a woman I'm not even with is moving in with someone. That'd be pathetic. To hell with this. When I first came to you, I told you that I wanted to be happy, and I followed your advice. And instead, I'm just miserable. How is this working for me?

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: It takes time.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: For a year, I've done everything you've asked, and everybody else is happy. I run on my treadmill. You just sit there and watch. You're a faith healer. You take advantage of people who want to believe. But there's nothing in your bag of tricks.

utterance.speaker: Nolan
utterance.content: House…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Whatever the answer is, you don't have it.
